reviewText: Basically you raise your cute little cubs by slaughtering as many rabbits, deer, rats, frogs and random eggs that you can find. You dedicate yourself to protecting them and feeding them. After about 1.5 hours of this they are fully grown and the ungratful little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s abandon you. Leaving you feeling without a purpose. You return to you den, follow lights, meet new mate, game ends. It felt very short particularly for a $15 game. It only takes 1h-1.5h per generation to complete. There are collectables which will unlock achievements. I didn't run into any wolves, only the blob which I kept clear of.\n\nI would give this a 6/10. The art is awesome and the idea of bring out our maternal instints was enjoyable, however game was VERY short and was not much varity of food or harsh events that tests your resolve. I had no trouble raising my kittens with rabbits and deer being my main food source. I reconmend, but this game should only be worth $5.

This is one of the rare games obviously designed by an artist, not an engineer. As a direct consequence, the game experience is within the emotional plane, not rational. In other words, this game is more about seeing and feeling than about competition and making rational choices.

Gameplay mechanics is all about struggling to keep the faily well-fed. So, from purely mechanical side of view, replayability is extremely limited. It typically takes 2~3 hours to complete the game.

The beauty of the game comes from the feelings it induces. The unique graphics (check screenshots, that is how it looks) is well combined with beautiful music and animation. The world looks good, and subject to seasonal changes that seem perfectly natural if you're do not watch them on purpose.

SUMMARY: the game leaves a deep psychological imprint and is extremely immersive. Way too simple game mechanics is likely to make subsequent games less interesting, but the experience is well worth the price.

Only an hour into the game and I suffered multiple performance issues; stuttering, seemingly random fps drops. You name it. I was audibly begging for the rain to stop because of the negetive effect it had on my frame rate. This should not be the case for a rig that can run modern games on ultra. The kicker though is the bugs in this game. The kittens got stuck in the turrain multiple times, running in spot. What finally killed my playthrough was when a kitten got stuck about 10 feet up in the middle of thin air. Suspended between bad code and my disappointment. Dispite my efforts to retrieve the youngling, it froze and died, which was very frustrating when trying to get all four to the end. 3/10 fix game and maybe i'll try again.

Great sequel! Great game even if you haven't played the first one too.

This game has pawed its way into my recent top-ten faves list! It keeps all of the charms of the previous game, while improving on a lot of things that the first Shelter lacked.

One of the issues the first game suffered from was linear gameplay that did not offer much replayability. This is not the case with Shelter 2; It's a HUGE world, no set place to go. Even after multiple playthroughs there's still plenty of things I haven't discovered.

Your goals are still simple and clear, and achieving those goals can always be a different experience (Some of my rabbit hunts end in bushes...). You're never quite sure where prey will spawn or how they'll evade you/detect you, and the hunt is always fun.

Another thing they really improved on with this game is indicating where (and who) your predators are, and how to escape them (mad respect for how they did their tutorial in this one). For the first Shelter, I get the whole bottom of the food chain = less control" deal for the badgers
date: but losing babies to predators felt kind of punishing.\n\nAll in all
recommended: the Lynx was an excellent choice of animal to feature in this game. Playing at the middle of the food chain provides thematic support for a good amount of player agency while leaving enough danger in to keep players from getting bored."

Having played the original Shelter, I halfway knew what to expect going in:  I'm a mother, I have babies, I have to feed them, and there's the potential for them to not survive.  Shelter 2 is deeper than that, however.  It's a story about motherhood that, in an instant, can let loose a good punch to the feels that will leave you feeling like an emotional train wreck.  On the reverse side of the coin, however, you could find a story about a momma lynx that lets you find a deeper level of happiness than you've ever felt before as you watch you kittens turn into full grown adults.  It all depends on YOUR actions as a Mom.

Keeping with the original Shelter, the developers have used the same stunning art style, with beautiful music that fits the theme of the game, and a loose storyline that helps to tie it all together.  The tactics you use to survive are similar to that of the original, as would be expected.

The first big difference from Shelter 1 -aside from the obvious species change- is that the gameplay has shifted from a linear progression through the levels, to a more open world, with many unique locations to explore and hunt.  Additionaly, weather and seasons are far more pronounced and aid the sense of time progression in this new world.

The other major difference is the way in which you must feed your babies.  In Shelter 1 you were an omnivorous badger, feeding largely on turnips and carrots, with the occasional frog, rodent, or even fox.  Essentially, alot of stationary sources of calories, with the occasional mobile meal.  In Shelter 2, however, you are a carnivorous lynx.  Gone are the days of walking up to a field of carrots and being set for life; now, you have to work for your food.

Would I recommed this game?

...

If you are the kind of person who enjoys games that poke at your soft, squishy emotions and, at times, take you from an enormous high, to a gut wrenching low, back to that euphoric high,  then yes, I would recommend it.

I have played this game for three hours this afternoon and have played through the story twice. I'm sure there is loads more to explore in the various landmasses that I haven't seen yet - I'm curious about the northernmost area but haven't seen much of it as it's hard to get there, and when I was there I was chased away by wolves! The soundtrack is gentle and appealing, and it gives great atmosphere as in Shelter 1. The graphics are more complicated than in 1, but retain the spirit of it. I haven't quite worked out whether there are distinct hunting techniques as in 1, but I have discovered a variety of food sources to feed myself and cubs with. I like being able to play the game with different lynx, but it would be nice to be able to return to previous individuals for repeat playthroughs or play with different littermates. It seems so far that you choose one cub per litter to continue the game with.
In brief, the pros are:
Good graphics, music, sound effects, lots of areas to explore, fun gameplay.
Cons:
The 'story' itself could be longer (i.e. it would be good if it took a bit longer for the cubs to grow up), and I imagine it could get a bit repetitive the more times you play through.
Overall, I would definitely recommend Shelter 2. It retains the spirit and emotional impact of Shelter 1 while expanding on gameplay. I look forward to seeing what else Might&Delight do with the concept and what they might add to Shelter 2 in the future! I will be returning to my lynx family as soon as my laptop cools down...

EDIT 12.3.15
I have now played for over 12 hours and I love this game even more. I have explored much more of the map but there is still more to see! I see different things wherever I go, and the environments change significantly from season to season. I thought I'd seen it all in one area, but then I went there in spring and was just in the right place to see ducks and swans with cygnets. I tried to catch them but fell in the stream instead! My lynx was not impressed. I've seen several different types of deer, loads of rabbits, wolves, birds, mice and frogs, and I'm pretty sure I stole some eggs from an owl in a tree. I have discovered that you don't have to go back to the den when you are prompted after your cubs leave home. I explored with my lynx Kirrim for over 5 game years and enjoyed every minute, even when Kirrim almost got eaten by wolves! I did experience some stuttering after 4 years or so, mainly in winter or near water and almost exclusively in the 'snowflake' area. Other than those brief occasions the game has performed perfectly at full graphics on my 2 year old laptop.
As I have played more I have noticed some similarities with WolfQuest, a wolf sim set in Yellowstone Park. The fatigue system and the 'sense' system are similar but not identical, and I think Shelter 2 implements them better. The AI problems and bugs that WolfQuest was plagued by are also absent in Shelter 2. If you enjoyed WolfQuest and wish it had been developed further, buy Shelter 2!

In the course of my gaming life I have destroyed empires both just and corrupt, condemned good men to death, bombed worlds to ash and brought worlds back from the edge of extinction. I have been the savior and executioner of planets, species, and entire galaxies many times over.

I really like this game. The concept is great and the gameplay is good. The art is unique and beautiful in it's own way.

That said, it is a bit lacking. The gameplay seems to consist of nothing but constant hunting and dangers are easily avoided by not venturing into the other areas. That really defeats the purpose.

Also the controls could really use some better joystick support. The movement is just a toggle between walking or sprinting, and it would have been much more immersive if it took full advantage of analog for the movement.

It does not seem that it would take much effort to make the game absolutely amazing. For this reason I still recommend it for purchase, but you may want to wait and watch it for a while, or grab it when it's on sale.

This is a lovely game, beautiful art and direction. There's a few issues that I ran into (it crashed once, and gave me an unresponsive black screen once in the couple of hours I played). There are a number of camera and ground clipping bugs as you play.\n\nIt's quite a short game, I guess the idea is to only raise a couple of cubs the first try, then to try again to raise more? I was hoping there would be a little more to it - maybe needing to have all four cubs raised to adulthood before the credits screen rolled would have been a more rewarding ending. The game has its flaws, but I did enjoy the experience.

I was a little nervous about buying this game, but figured I'd give it a try as I do love realistic animal simulations. By and large, I was pretty impressed (got two cubs to adulthood; the other two starved to death or something)

THE GOOD
The concept
Free roaming. However, if you want a game that tells you what to do and what the next move should be, you probably won't like this one
The sensing for prey is a nice feature, but it doesn't always work; I've gone through parts thinking there's no prey only to have rabbits suddenly racing away from me
Different prey, and different tactics.  It's not enough to bump into a deer; you need to actually jump on its back
Different seasons and day and night
The ability to play a fresh game with one of your offspring

THE BAD
The map is very bad. Unlike games such as WolfQuest, where you had a built in compass so you could at least tell which way you were facing and where you were likely to end up, this one is just a few crosshatchings and weird symbols and only shows an extreme close up. Your little lynx character doesn't even match your direction, so the only way to know which way you're traveling is to check the map, go straight for a little while, and then check it again and compare the two. This isn't actually much of an issue when you're roaming around, but at the end of the game you're supposed to return to your den. Unfortunately, there's no way of finding it or even knowing which direction to travel in. Frustrating.
There's no variety in the cubs; you're stuck giving birth to a litter of one white, one black, one brown and one tawny. I can understand that playing as a male lynx would involve an entirely separate game, but the number of cubs and their colors could have been randomized.

AND THE JUST PLAIN MISC
It would have been nice to have a popup saying, Your cub Kir has just starved to death" or something along those lines. It's not hard to figure out when that happens but it would save me a trip back. The cubs do let out a yowl when they die

Having played the original Shelter, I halfway knew what to expect going in:  I'm a mother, I have babies, I have to feed them, and there's the potential for them to not survive.  Shelter 2 is deeper than that, however.  It's a story about motherhood that, in an instant, can let loose a good punch to the feels that will leave you feeling like an emotional train wreck.  On the reverse side of the coin, however, you could find a story about a momma lynx that lets you find a deeper level of happiness than you've ever felt before as you watch you kittens turn into full grown adults.  It all depends on YOUR actions as a Mom.

Keeping with the original Shelter, the developers have used the same stunning art style, with beautiful music that fits the theme of the game, and a loose storyline that helps to tie it all together.  The tactics you use to survive are similar to that of the original, as would be expected.

The first big difference from Shelter 1 -aside from the obvious species change- is that the gameplay has shifted from a linear progression through the levels, to a more open world, with many unique locations to explore and hunt.  Additionaly, weather and seasons are far more pronounced and aid the sense of time progression in this new world.

The other major difference is the way in which you must feed your babies.  In Shelter 1 you were an omnivorous badger, feeding largely on turnips and carrots, with the occasional frog, rodent, or even fox.  Essentially, alot of stationary sources of calories, with the occasional mobile meal.  In Shelter 2, however, you are a carnivorous lynx.  Gone are the days of walking up to a field of carrots and being set for life; now, you have to work for your food.

Would I recommed this game?

...

If you are the kind of person who enjoys games that poke at your soft, squishy emotions and, at times, take you from an enormous high, to a gut wrenching low, back to that euphoric high,  then yes, I would recommend it.

I have played this game for three hours this afternoon and have played through the story twice. I'm sure there is loads more to explore in the various landmasses that I haven't seen yet - I'm curious about the northernmost area but haven't seen much of it as it's hard to get there, and when I was there I was chased away by wolves! The soundtrack is gentle and appealing, and it gives great atmosphere as in Shelter 1. The graphics are more complicated than in 1, but retain the spirit of it. I haven't quite worked out whether there are distinct hunting techniques as in 1, but I have discovered a variety of food sources to feed myself and cubs with. I like being able to play the game with different lynx, but it would be nice to be able to return to previous individuals for repeat playthroughs or play with different littermates. It seems so far that you choose one cub per litter to continue the game with.
In brief, the pros are:
Good graphics, music, sound effects, lots of areas to explore, fun gameplay.
Cons:
The 'story' itself could be longer (i.e. it would be good if it took a bit longer for the cubs to grow up), and I imagine it could get a bit repetitive the more times you play through.
Overall, I would definitely recommend Shelter 2. It retains the spirit and emotional impact of Shelter 1 while expanding on gameplay. I look forward to seeing what else Might&Delight do with the concept and what they might add to Shelter 2 in the future! I will be returning to my lynx family as soon as my laptop cools down...

EDIT 12.3.15
I have now played for over 12 hours and I love this game even more. I have explored much more of the map but there is still more to see! I see different things wherever I go, and the environments change significantly from season to season. I thought I'd seen it all in one area, but then I went there in spring and was just in the right place to see ducks and swans with cygnets. I tried to catch them but fell in the stream instead! My lynx was not impressed. I've seen several different types of deer, loads of rabbits, wolves, birds, mice and frogs, and I'm pretty sure I stole some eggs from an owl in a tree. I have discovered that you don't have to go back to the den when you are prompted after your cubs leave home. I explored with my lynx Kirrim for over 5 game years and enjoyed every minute, even when Kirrim almost got eaten by wolves! I did experience some stuttering after 4 years or so, mainly in winter or near water and almost exclusively in the 'snowflake' area. Other than those brief occasions the game has performed perfectly at full graphics on my 2 year old laptop.
As I have played more I have noticed some similarities with WolfQuest, a wolf sim set in Yellowstone Park. The fatigue system and the 'sense' system are similar but not identical, and I think Shelter 2 implements them better. The AI problems and bugs that WolfQuest was plagued by are also absent in Shelter 2. If you enjoyed WolfQuest and wish it had been developed further, buy Shelter 2!

I won't lie, there were a few stressed filled moments. I verbally cursed deer and rabbits for being faster than I when I needed the kill most. My heart raced as one of my cubs grew weak and no longer followed me, leading me on a desperate hunt to kill ANYTHING to save her.
Naming your cubs at the beginning is a mistake. Giving names to these kittens that mew in hunger is a mistake.

Also, ♥♥♥♥ deer. Let me kill you, you ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s!

You play a mother lynx initaly and raise four cubs. There are some dangers that I have found in the game such as wolves and some moose as well as this darkness that kills you if you touch it, but it only comes out during the nighttime in the three tree area of the game.

Beware the darkness it's super freaky and I didn't notice it my first playthrough (it just rises out of the large lake in the three trees area). It killed one of my cubs and when I got close too close for a minute I couldn't see.

For the wolves there are little platforms that the wolves don't jump up on (doesn't make much sense) but they can't follow up there so that is a way to avoid them.

This game is fun and relaxing for me.

reviewText: Absolutely love this game.  It has my heart going from second one all the way up till the end. The open map and no words of guidance besides keeping your family alive is fantastic.\n\nIt's beautiful.  It's cute.  Buy it :)
Wonderful, immersive, emotional

One of my all time favorite virtual experiences!

WARNING: Be open minded or don't buy.. This is not a game that u can find hours and hours of endless action in. It is more of a short story of being a mother in the wild.

The emotions the music brings to the everchanging seasons, weather and darkness is just amazing. The fact that there is nothing more than listening and watching your cubs to tell u if they are tired/hungry is great, brings out a natural survival mindset.. carry the slow and tired ones for a while.. listen to their cries, feed individual cubs as u need to.  Amazing game.

When the music flows with the seasons and u are walking miles in search of bigger game and you realise a cub is missing.. You turn around in a frantic search for signs of life.. You can hear yelps from your cub but you are having a hard time locating it..the yelps stop..simply a sad moment and makes u bond to the ones you have still with you.

The group grows to a size to take down deer for a bigger feast..Eventually learning to hunt for their own meat, which leads them to go their own ways in the world.  Then, all alone you find yourself walking in the warm spring sun again.. in search of a mate to start all over and continue the family tree.

!!!Play this as a short but emotional movie and you will very much enjoy this, be careful playing this as strictly a cat sim!!!

Even though it is a great cat sim, most sims are boring for most people, so dont miss out on the story the devs put in place!

Game score 2/10

reviewText: I. Love. This. Game. All animal lovers should play this game. It is fun, and the best part is you get to see your lynx babies grow into adults. :') This is one of the funnest games I've ever played and it is worth the money. Good job, Might & Delight!

I've played through the whole game and even started a new one, playing as one of my surviving offspring.\n\nYou play as a mother Lynx and your goal is to feed your young so they can survive to maturity. Simple premise, and it doesn't get much more complex besides a few random events that I think require more than one playthrough. This game is for people who enjoy ambience and reflection. Different areas of the map are designated by symbols. I don't believe it is necessary to visit each one, but they have their own feel and you can discover other environments and animals that aren't found in the starting area (deer, frogs, and bird nests.) There isn't much to hunting besides anticipating an animals movement and then getting close enough for the Lynx to grab them. The adventure element isn't a requirement, but if you aren't a curious person who enjoys exploring, then you probably shouldn't buy this game. In my humble opinion, additional objectives besides feeding your kittens only exist if you make them, and I think this game is meant to be instinctual, rather than cerebral. I would have preferred a longer game with more to do, but still thoroughly enjoyed my time with it. Also, great soundtrack.

reviewText: I Love Love this game. The GRAPHICS the CYCLE OF LIFE the VERY VERY SAD ENDING and my favorite part the CUBS.   VERY,VERY adictive game.AND VERY SAD.GET THE GAME NOW

This game isn't for everyone. I JUST finished it, and I have to say it left me feeling and thinking about a few things.

First off, it's a very quiet game. There's not a whole lot that goes on or a cohesive storyline. The game is about taking care of your cubs, watching them grow up, and that's it. There's a beautiful ending and little narration, but it gets the point across completely. I won't spoil it for you, but the ending is very open to interpatation. Which is something I like.

Quite frankly, the game is very easy. What I enjoyed most about the game was the artwork. It reminded me a bit of paper mache and origami thrown together. The artwork is simply GORGEOUS and the map is huge. Really huge! I've only explored about half of it at this point. There is of course a hardmode, and once you finish the game you can actually continue playing as one of the cubs you've raised. You can even name them at the beginning of the game.

As I said before, if you're not a fan of quiet, artistic games. This may not be the game for you. It's very quiet. It's just the focus of a mother lynx trying to raise her babies. The soundtrack is relaxing, and quite frankly I could listen to it all day. It's that beautiful.

If I had to nitpick I would have to say I feel the game is way to expensive. While it is beautiful, I feel for the time you play it is not worth the price tag. I feel the game is more worth $5 rather than $15 like the price asks for. Still, overall a good game. If you want a nice experience and a quiet hour or two. This is a good game to try out.

Shelter 2 has to be one of the most beautiful games i have ever played, both visually and with the nature of the gameplay itself. From start to finish, it is rather difficult to not get attached to your babies. The story of a mother lynx is seriously a tragic but really amazing one that makes you feel like you're actually there. The unusual appearance of the game adds a real special touch as well. The controls are simple and easy to use, yet there still is a challenge when hunting.

Over all, there was nothing really bad, but i found a few glitches as i played. First, I discovered this one: I had played another full game, it was my 3rd gen to a new tree. Upon completing this game with 2 of my cubs I had found out when seeing my family tree that it seemed that none of my cubs survived, as i could not select any of them to start a new generation. It was disappointing mostly because i had to start a whole new family, but not the end of the world. Another problem i had found had to do with the mountain expansion. When you enter an area that is near the waterfall there are three ledges that you must jump up. For whatever reason, when my cubs became medium sized they could no longer get past the last ledge. They would just kinda run in place at the edge and wouldn't be able to follow me anywhere. (( Its kinda funny to look at, but it got a bit annoying. ))

Overall, this game can be a tad bit buggy, but Shelter 2 is most certainly worth the money.

I've been eyeing this game for a long time here and there, and when I finally got a gaming computer and it went on sale, I had my chance to try it out. That said, I wasn't completely let down, but it didn't come close to blowing me out of the water either. I honestly can't decide whether to give it a thumbs up or not because it has good aspects, but a lot of it is very stale and lacking in potential.

The art style is great and incredibly unique, I've never seen anything quite like it before. It manages to look very hand-painted despite being 3d rendered, and isn't so bizarre that its disorienting. The main selling point for this game is probably the art style.

On to less appreciable things: gameplay, potential, and overall opinion.

I've got a beast of a computer, but I think this game is just coded in such a way that it begins to shoot itself in the foot after 15 minutes of playtime. Framerate goes right in the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ regardless of graphics settings, and I had to close and reopen the game every so often just to be able to even play it. (Maybe something to do with the data endlessley compiling and not wiping itself when you leave an area and it becomes no longer relevant? Who knows.)

In between dealing with the game running like molasses for no discernible reason, I found myself struggling to rationalize a reason to play it beyond getting a few easy achievements. The point is simple: sniff, find a rabbit or whatever, run at it and hope the game doesn't lag so badly you can't catch it before your kittens starve. There's no direction- you just wander around and kill stuff over and over until your kittens grow up and start killing their own stuff, by which point you are mostly superfluous- and then they leave, and you go home. That's it.

A few freak events make it kind of interesting, but its mostly just annoying because the fires and lightning strikes and floods are almost guaranteed to kill at least one kitten if you don't run like hell, and they look choppy as if they were thrown in last minute. I spent a good two minutes in a flood" before I realized what it was supposed to be
date: I just thought the game was glitching at first.\n\nBasically
recommended: get this game only if it goes on a reeealllyy good sale and you don't have high expectations."

Shelter 2 is a nice improvment of the original Shelter game.
You first take control of a prenant mover Lynx in an exciting tutorial level that does its job of teaching new players how to play, as well as be part of the story and keep players in the game rather than draw them out and lessen the experience.

Life is hard as a mother lynx, and keeping all four of your cubs alive and fed is a difficult challenge, only made even harder by the seasons and preditors.

The art style is beautifully presented, and much more satuated and defined than in the original Shelter game, which is a big improvment.
I liked the open world that you were able to explore, but missed the day and night cycles in the original Shelter, but changes are changes.

If you like open world survival and cute cubs, then this is the game for you, coupled with an amazing soundtrack its worth it.
Great game beutifull graphics so realistic but i cant buy the mountains pack dont know why???

A beautiful game that you can continue to play! Soon though, it can get a little tireing, but after a while, you'll be drawn back! Reccomended for it's unique graphics, amazing storyline, and the truely strong emotions the game makes you feel.
This game reminds you what is important in life
This game is really cool, trying to micromanage your cubs is hard as hell.\n\nI only have 0.6 hours because I lost one of my cubs and I'm too scared to go check if its alive.

a fun game that allows you to explore the wilderness,there will be a DLC coming out soon that adds new threats making the game a lot harder and more fun!,i wish the wolves would be in more area's then just the Tundra area,but beggars can't be choosers,if you loose all the cubs the result is unknown,at least for me,you can choose to explore the world and there are so many cool things to find,such as  a Frozen and Dead Mammoth,in the lake there is also this Cave i found,Nothing in it but a neat lil thing and there's an ice tunnel in the tundra's,I haven't explored EVERYTHING yet but if all your cubs die or if they all grow up i recommend not going to the den afterwards and exploring the world,all in all,a fun game to play over and over as many times as you want,I do wish each litter of cubs were different,Like if Kir had a litter (since if your cubs grow up they can have kids of their own) they'd all look different,and you have one that looks like a previous sibling,Rival families of lynx s? i doubt it but that's fun to think about,when the Mountain DLC comes out i recommend getting it since its going to add SO MUCH to the game e  u e

Wonderful. Or cute if you could call it that.

You play as a Lynx mother tending to her cubs feeding them and making sure they grow up to adulthood. There are dangers ahead as well as you gotta make sure they eat enough and stay out of the wolfs grasp. There is also a family tree, witch gives you the choice of letting one of your surviving cubs to bring the new generation forth.

I have a tendency to grow attached to games like these. It has a certain artful mood about it that just makes it breathtaking when playing. And I love when a story is basically told without words. It's short though, and if it weren't for the survival mode, witch gives the game a harder edge, it wouldn't be as fun playing every time.

It's the kind of game I like to sit down with on the evening just playing through. Like instead of reading a book or doing my work. If you like short games and the kind that stings you a little with love in your heart, then you should give it a try.

I had a feeling going into this game that I would either love it or hate it, and I absolutely loved it.

I was on a Skype voice chat with one of my friends while playing for the first time, and she got to hear me coo and swear over my cubs, with continually counting them one by one to make sure they were all with me. When I lost the first one, I was in tears, there was a lot of screaming and noises that were probably not human while I was frantically running around trying to get food to feed my remaining three, then remaining two...

I only had one cub survive on my first playthrough, and I was sobbing when I saw that darling go off on their own into the world. Because my baby grew up and everything was wonderful.

I am still exploring, still trying to find everything that others are talking about (where the hell are the deer? I can't find them anywhere!). My second playthrough managed to get all my cubs to adulthood, and there was lots of happy crying to see them go off into the world on their own.

I really recommend it, and honestly can't wait to see what the DLC adds.
I would best describe this game as an Animal Simulator, and a Damned good one at that!\n\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M7nQx_0yVQw&list=PLNtPp4M-LVW-RJYbhJha2iqZ7wSZOZI5H&index=1
Wonderful game. The first game I have purchased on Steam. I recommended this game to all of my friends.

Amazing game, really. I love the animations and the art is so unique. The music is so calm and all these features combined just makes it all the more awesome. The game doesn't take long to complete, but especially the first time playing, it is exetremely fun!

I find is amazing how emotionaly attatched you get to these viritual cubs. The game dosn't take long to finnish, but you'll put an hour or two into it and its absolutly worth it. Its a great game that you can really start feeling like you are a part of.\n\n12 out of 10, gold stars all around! Love it!
A great game all around! If only more Indie studios would be as ambitious as M&D instead of over saturating the market with 2D nostalgia games.

It seems like a calming, heart warming story about a mother Lynx and her children... Until one of them starves to death or gets eaten by wolves. Then you sit there, tears in your eyes, wondering why the hell did you even buy this game?

I love this game even though one of my four pups died I am in love with this game. This game brought the mother out of me and to see them grow up and leave it made my heart ache but in a good way.



Spoilers: maybe
In the end when you get to see your pups again wow they grew up and you can then start a family with the kids that you raised the ending makes me cry.
Ya this game is good.

reviewText: Wonderful game. The first game I have purchased on Steam. I recommended this game to all of my friends.

Or at least something in the dog family, but if you don't do a shelter 3, it is fine with me, I can see how hard it must be for you. But anyways, this is an awesome game, and I love it!

Ah! This Is amazing!! I do believe this is a game for all animal lovers out there. Perhaps for Shelter 3 (If there is going to be one) you could do a mother raccoon? Anyway, I love this game, I cant get enough of it!

This game is really something. I don't often write reviews but this game really does deserve one. There is not alot to do in this game and its not really that difficult to play..however it is really well bulit and fantastic to play. Also if you, like most people out there have any respect for your mothers, you will love the With special thanks" message at the end. That really topped off what was already an amazing game! Thank you"

Very very fun game!! I play it when I have freetime and I have been looking for a game like this one for a very long time! This game fits all my needs, does not need a very good computer and is very fun. I love hunting for food and giving it to my  little cats! Very fun game and I definitly recommend it!
greatest game of all time\n

Before I start, let me be clear that it was very hard to give this game a no" recommendation. I don't want to give it a "no" but I can't honestly give it a "yes" either. If there was ever a neutral option
date: this game would definitely be it.\n\nI've played the original Shelter and loved it. It was difficult
recommended: it was varied. The babies were hard to raise and I got ridiculously attached to them. The art style was gorgeous! Therefore
hoursPlayed: when Shelter 2 was announced
voteText: I got quite excited about it.\n\nUnfortunately
helpfulPercent: it feels like everything that made the original Shelter good is missing from Shelter 2. This time the game lets you free roam
votesHelpful: and while this does give the game a much more expansive feeling
votesTotal: it also causes some of the situational charm of the original to be lost.\n\nI remember a section in the original where I was walking through a pitch-black forest with eerie predator noises echoing all around me
votesFunny: only able to see a few feet ahead. I was worried sick that something was going to leap out of the darkness and steal one of my babies if I took my eyes off them for just one second.\n\nThere is none of that tension in Shelter 2. I never felt under pressure to find food
commentsCount: as rabbits were consistently plentiful and a bit too easy to catch. There were also not as many predators. I got followed by a fox a few times
column16: but each time I cornered and killed him within about 30 seconds.\n\nThe most tense moment I had was when some wolves appeared from nowhere. One chased me and knocked me down. The screen faded to black and when I woke up
column17: one of my kittens was gone. It all happened too fast to be a tense moment
column18: and I must admit
column19: I didn't feel any sadness about the missing kit.\n\nOverall
column20: I still think this series has potential. If you have not played either Shelter or Shelter 2
column21:
I would really suggest that you go and play the first one before deciding whether to purchase Shelter 2.

Pros:
- The art style is absolutely gorgeous
column23:
atmospheric soundtrack.
- Controls feel very smooth.
- Much more expansive world.

Cons:
- Repetitive. Most of your time will be spent chasing rabbits.
- The tutorial tips are a bit too minimal. They lack explanation and function in favour of looking stylish.
- Too easy. Food is plentiful and I honestly didn't feel like my kits were at risk at any time.
- No replay value. You can raise more cubs
column24: but you'll still spend most of your time chasing rabbits.\n"

reviewText:
Other reviews put a bit too much emotion into what this game really is.

No doubt, it's different and relaxing. And in the end it is really sad
However it's short and figuring out the mechanics is frustrating. When a cub was starting to die I felt less sadness and more frustration because if you don't play it correctly the cubs most certainly will be pining for your attention often.

If you can help it you should opt to play this game in a focused environment where you can 100% immerse and devote yourself to creating the world to suite you. If the game was longer, with more content, and better controls the replay value would up tremendously.

All in all, it's a roleplay game. If you can get it discount you should grab it. The art style is lovely.

I have to say, with the new updates to the game my opinion has completely been swayed.  I thought before that while adorable and somewhat suspenceful at times, that the game didn't have enough drive to get me out there exploring.  Well, with all the new content, added prey, and what not I have to say I just spent two hours exploring a LONG ways away from the den.  Loved every moment of it.

I love this game! But i would like more DLC:s that unlockes more animals. 90% of the time I´m running around hunting rabbits (although it´s pretty fun, it gets a bit monotonic). Absolutely fantastic landscapes!! <3

Shelter 2 is a game wherein you are a mama lynx who must care for her four adorable newborn kittens in the cold, unforgiving world of nature. Fun! Concept is simple enough, execution is quality. All of the models move and feel like an actual lynx, and the animals that populate the world all seem realistic and lively. The environment itself is sizeable as well, full of collectables for those of you with a touch of OCD, and the art direction, though not realistic, is a beautiful shade of stylization I thoroughly enjoyed. Frame-rate is smooth, and the game isn't particularly buggy.

The story here is a story of survival. It's a heartwarming story of parental pride and affection if you let it be, really. The game lets you name each of the four kittens at the start, which helps to bond you to them, and the adorable mews and mannerisms of the little lynx kittens bring them to life. Of course, it can also be an unforgiving tale of the circle of life and the inevitable death of all things cute and loveable. Like that one time when me and the kids were scavenging for food and some wolves came upon us. I tried fighting off this one wolf, only to get my ♥♥♥ kicked and watch as the pack stole away with one of my babies. Honestly, that was one of the worst feelings I have had in a long time from a game. Seriously. If your kittens survive though, you are able to continue the lineage of lynx-dom through one of them, and you can track your family tree, which is a neat little touch.

The main objective of the game is simple: keep everyone fed. Most kills will feed one or two kittens at a time; only nests of eggs or deer will be able to feed the whole family. You often have to chose between eating your kills yourself, which will boost your stamina for a time and allow you to hunt more effectively, or to give your kills to your children, who desperately need it. Later in their juvenille stage, the kittens will actually assist in hunting. It's a simple goal.

ALL THAT POSITIVE STUFF BEING SAID, there are some issues with the game. The most pressing would probably be the lack of actual threat in the game. Quite simply put, Mother Lynx cannot die. At all. The kittens can, of course, from starvation, abandonment, environmental hazards or predators, but once you learn where the predators actually spawn (and in normal mode it's only in one area), you'll probably never lose a kitten again. And there's only wolves, too, which is kind of boring after a while. Lynx kittens have to worry about swooping birds, crashing trees, cougars, coyotes or even other scary adult lynx...there's so much more that could be included in this game that I would love to see--a tracking mechanic for predators, weather impacts, more environmental hazards. I would've liked to have seen multiple species you could play as--sort of like Tokyo Jungle--the more you play the more capable creatures you can unlock. There is replayability value there, but it's just not enough.

I should mention there is a Survival Mode, which is sort of like a step up from your normal difficulty. Stamina doesn't regen as fast or through all the same methods; food is more scarce and migratory, and predators are a bit more difficult to deal with as well. I really enjoyed what little taste I had of Survival Mode, but again, it fell very flat after a while.

Inevitably, the game feels very bare-bones as it is, which is unfortunate because what is there is really good. As they say, variety is the spice of life, and Shelter 2 could stand to see a bit more diversity in its core product. I would recommend buying it on sale and only if a quality game with a more artistic direction appeals to you. In the same way games like Shadow of the Colossus, Monster Hunter or the beloved Hatoful Boyfriend simply aren't for everyone (and that's okay), Shelter 2 isn't meant to appeal to a wide audience. What is there, though, is very touching and presented with quality and pride. If you have the money and are interested, pick it up. I hope you aren't disappointed.
A very slow-paced, yet exciting and touching adventure. Certainly not for everyone though

I played it for a little while, then, as I was happilly raising my kittens, an eagle swooped down and took one of my babies and flew away. I then began crying.\n\n11/10 would cry over the brutality of nature again - but not for a little while I need some time to recover
in a world that is mainly shooters, its nice to find a game that is a bit more laid back even if it is a strange game.

I bought this game as there was a sale and I wanted to try something new.
I seriously do not regret my decision one bit!
I love the art style and I love the simplisity of the whole game,
I also really love the small story snippits...
Emotional surprise at the end.

This game is a mother Lynx simulator. There are different landscapes to explore, ambient music and artistic visuals. Surroundings are quite detailed, you feel this world is living. I have liked the game and I will play it more to explore different areas and get achievements. I would not recommend this game to kids or sensitive persons though as seeing your cubs dying from starvation is very stressfull.\n\nThere are some critic reviews and those people are right, there is not much to do in this game. But it is more about perceiving than doing. Relax and enjoy the beauty, aesthetics and emotions. I think it's better to think of Shelter 2 as of an interactive piece of art rather than a game and I like it alot. If it sounds boring to you don't buy it...

I bought the game bundle and I do recommend both games but if you are looking to only buy one then here are the pros and cons for both:
Shelter:Pros: More exciting/More Danger
Shelter:Cons: Not really an open world, the story always ends the same, no family tree
Shelter 2:Pros: A huge world explore and the mountains dlc too.
Shelter 2:Cons:If you buy the base game (no mountains etc.) then there are only a few threats apart from starvation in the game the mist/fog and wolves do if your looking for a more challenging game shelter 1 is for you. However the mountains dlc adds new threats bears/hawks/fox etc.

This game looks great and is a great idea... but sadly lacks any content to keep you playing, Basically you have 4 cubs which you need to feed, (so hunting is the game) and catching rabbits is so easy, then after a few seasons the cubs get bigger (season can be 5-10 minutes) then when the cubs are old enough they leave you.. you then go back to the den and sleep" and thats it.. you can start a new game with one of the cubs that ran away.. rinse repeat.. boring
date: sorry.. but you should save your money on this one."

It seems like a calming, heart warming story about a mother Lynx and her children... Until one of them starves to death or gets eaten by wolves. Then you sit there, tears in your eyes, wondering why the hell did you even buy this game?
A great game all around! If only more Indie studios would be as ambitious as M&D instead of over saturating the market with 2D nostalgia games.

Shelter was and is a beautiful and amazing game, but Shelter 2 is complete perfection.
I played this game and, at the time, my only complaint was that there were no steam achievements.
Since then there has been an update and aside from achievements being added they fixed a few bugs that had been bothering me (such as not all the cubs showing up in family tree despite all surviving) and allowed the map and collectables to carry over when starting from scratch.
This game is everything I could have ever dreamed and so much more.
If you have not bought this game; buy it. If you don't like this game; you're not playing it right.
You are a mother lynx with four adorable cubs, who you raise and then can play as, continuing the family line. You can name them, hunt critters, have threats come night, and the soundtrack and graphics are absolutely gorgeous.
Shelter 2 is my favourite game of all time, and if you aren't squealing with delight at the four little lynx cubs who mew and follow you and pur and just generally be adorable, then you clearly haven't bought the game.

100/10, Cried, Smiled, Laughed, Loved <3

First playthrough.

All but one starved to dead.

Second Playthrough.

All reached adulthood. Then we were attacked by a wolf pack. Lost one to the pack. Lost the rest to starvation from leaving a different way than we arrived. Been feeding them deer for while now and since I had to leave the deer rich area I could not catch enough rabbits to feed them all in the unknown area. No survivors.

Third Playthrough.

All but one survived. Acheivement.

Fourth Playthrough and onward.

All survive. Just don't go into the tundra and avoid the swamp.


Would die of heartbreak again. 10/10.
Lacks the connection with your cubs that the first game did so well, which leaves this game with very little to praise.

I definately recommend this for all gamers. It's a little repetitive, but it makes up for that with cuteness and adventure. It makes me feel like I am the lynx. If your into games where you travel and raise young, than this is for you!
A beautiful game; refreshingly different graphics, addicting gameplay that really messes with your emotions, and plenty of replay value. Definitely worth the purchase.
This is a mothersday game not a survival game.\n\nYou have been warned.

The art is beautiful and gives a good feel to the game. The controls are simple and the game is to protect and care for your cubs. The instint as a parent kicks in right away as you have to feed your cubs which trumps your human reluctance to harm animals you need to hunt. The game looks allot better then the trailer when you put the graphics on high. My only gripe so far is that the game advertises full crontroller support but the controller only works on the menu not in game. On a side note I feel as if the game may be a bit too open ended in the sense that it is not always clear what you should be doing. A way to fix thius might be to add more dangers or include some kind of built-in intiution to let the player know they are on track. As much as I love the game and the concept which feels good I'd like there to be more urgency in the gameplay. I suppose that might ruin the explorative nature of the game tho but a good mix of the two would be ideal.

Do i recommened this game? Yeah, you could say that. This is one of the best games I have ever played, on a scale of one to ten this game would be some where around...11. Even though it is a quick game, you somehow get the most nostalgic, sentimental feeling at the end of this. I honestly cannot understand why people would give this a negtive review (no offence). The graphics are incredible, it looks like papier mache animals are walking over an intracite quilt, making it more interesting than ever. Although be warned, if one of your kits dies, you might feel like jumping of a bridge into the river that your tears have made :'(. 10/10, abousultely amazing game, buy this right now!

The gameplay the soundtrack and the visuals are so f*cking good in this game. You play as a lynx and raise 4 cubs till their adulthood, and every second is a ticking clock for one of them to expire. Feeding for 5 lynx's is not an easy feat, but once mastered this game becomes extremely fun. With a harder difficulty to keep you on your toes.\nWhile content in this game is lacking currently, the Dev's are still adding things that the players want. Shelter 2 has A lot of replayability, and lots of vast areas to explore. If u like Cats, and you like hunting and survival, I highly recommend this game.

Although i reccomend this game i would only reccomend it to certain people, this game was great the first time but it felt very repetitive and short, if it took longer for the cubs to mature and there were more options to do stuff, stuff  like making your own dens ina  bigger map, have more dangers occur, i would feel like it would be gr8 m8, dont get me worng great game for the first time palying through but idont think i would want to expand the family tree in fear of it getting to repetitive and boring.

This game isn't for everyone. I JUST finished it, and I have to say it left me feeling and thinking about a few things.

First off, it's a very quiet game. There's not a whole lot that goes on or a cohesive storyline. The game is about taking care of your cubs, watching them grow up, and that's it. There's a beautiful ending and little narration, but it gets the point across completely. I won't spoil it for you, but the ending is very open to interpatation. Which is something I like.

Quite frankly, the game is very easy. What I enjoyed most about the game was the artwork. It reminded me a bit of paper mache and origami thrown together. The artwork is simply GORGEOUS and the map is huge. Really huge! I've only explored about half of it at this point. There is of course a hardmode, and once you finish the game you can actually continue playing as one of the cubs you've raised. You can even name them at the beginning of the game.

As I said before, if you're not a fan of quiet, artistic games. This may not be the game for you. It's very quiet. It's just the focus of a mother lynx trying to raise her babies. The soundtrack is relaxing, and quite frankly I could listen to it all day. It's that beautiful.

If I had to nitpick I would have to say I feel the game is way to expensive. While it is beautiful, I feel for the time you play it is not worth the price tag. I feel the game is more worth $5 rather than $15 like the price asks for. Still, overall a good game. If you want a nice experience and a quiet hour or two. This is a good game to try out.

This game is so beautiful and can be funny with comedic commentary.  In this game, you play as a mother lynx.  You give birth to cubs, and you must feed them.  Throughout the game, you may face struggles with gathering food and keeping your cubs alive.  There are many new dangers your cubs can face in the new Mountains DLC, such as bears, foxes, hawks/eagles, and starvation.  Before the expansion, your only dangers were wolves and starvation.  There is also a survival mode, which makes prey scarce.\nTo play this game, you must have patience.  It takes an hour to two hours to fully grow your cubs up.  There is also no end to this game as you can have one of your offspring have cubs as well.  There is a family tree in the main menu that indicates this.\nOverall, the graphics of this game are gorgeous and it is a very beautiful game in it's self; the circle of life.  I recommend this game 100%.  One warning is that there is blood in this game.  Your cubs may die, and that's just how it plays out.  Have fun!

reviewText:
Shelter 2: Mountains Review

The world of Might and Delight’s Shelter 2 is barren but beautiful. Unlike its predecessor, Shelter, the open world set-up creates a stark and unforgiving landscape, where the possibility that anything could happen, might happen.

In the first game of this series, Shelter, it was very much about the experience of survival and --

A beautiful game; refreshingly different graphics, addicting gameplay that really messes with your emotions, and plenty of replay value. Definitely worth the purchase.

The art is beautiful and gives a good feel to the game. The controls are simple and the game is to protect and care for your cubs. The instint as a parent kicks in right away as you have to feed your cubs which trumps your human reluctance to harm animals you need to hunt. The game looks allot better then the trailer when you put the graphics on high. My only gripe so far is that the game advertises full crontroller support but the controller only works on the menu not in game. On a side note I feel as if the game may be a bit too open ended in the sense that it is not always clear what you should be doing. A way to fix thius might be to add more dangers or include some kind of built-in intiution to let the player know they are on track. As much as I love the game and the concept which feels good I'd like there to be more urgency in the gameplay. I suppose that might ruin the explorative nature of the game tho but a good mix of the two would be ideal.

I love this game and i think its fun. However it has a few things i dont understand like when my cubs grow up they left me but i cant continue the story with the cubs. So um ya. I think its a great game. I think they should add where the lynx can swim instead of dying 3 feet in the water. I recommend this game.
Love this game, the baby kitties are so cute I'm going to die. Very breathtaking game!!!

This is my favorite game, I've played it over and over and can't get enough, if you love animals, and want to find a good simulator type game, this is number one, it's fun, pulls at the heart strings in a way you won't believe, it's one of the best games I've ever played, if you've played it and are addicted do #addicted share your love for wild life! =)

The game is difficult at first but I'd actually suggest never using normal mode if you really want the threat of cub-loss hanging over your shoulder.

reviewText: I have to say, with the new updates to the game my opinion has completely been swayed.  I thought before that while adorable and somewhat suspenceful at times, that the game didn't have enough drive to get me out there exploring.  Well, with all the new content, added prey, and what not I have to say I just spent two hours exploring a LONG ways away from the den.  Loved every moment of it.

I love this game! But i would like more DLC:s that unlockes more animals. 90% of the time I´m running around hunting rabbits (although it´s pretty fun, it gets a bit monotonic). Absolutely fantastic landscapes!! <3

Before I start, let me be clear that it was very hard to give this game a no" recommendation. I don't want to give it a "no" but I can't honestly give it a "yes" either. If there was ever a neutral option
date: this game would definitely be it.\n\nI've played the original Shelter and loved it. It was difficult
recommended: it was varied. The babies were hard to raise and I got ridiculously attached to them. The art style was gorgeous! Therefore
hoursPlayed: when Shelter 2 was announced
voteText: I got quite excited about it.\n\nUnfortunately
helpfulPercent: it feels like everything that made the original Shelter good is missing from Shelter 2. This time the game lets you free roam
votesHelpful: and while this does give the game a much more expansive feeling
votesTotal: it also causes some of the situational charm of the original to be lost.\n\nI remember a section in the original where I was walking through a pitch-black forest with eerie predator noises echoing all around me
votesFunny: only able to see a few feet ahead. I was worried sick that something was going to leap out of the darkness and steal one of my babies if I took my eyes off them for just one second.\n\nThere is none of that tension in Shelter 2. I never felt under pressure to find food
commentsCount: as rabbits were consistently plentiful and a bit too easy to catch. There were also not as many predators. I got followed by a fox a few times
column16: but each time I cornered and killed him within about 30 seconds.\n\nThe most tense moment I had was when some wolves appeared from nowhere. One chased me and knocked me down. The screen faded to black and when I woke up
column17: one of my kittens was gone. It all happened too fast to be a tense moment
column18: and I must admit
column19: I didn't feel any sadness about the missing kit.\n\nOverall
column20: I still think this series has potential. If you have not played either Shelter or Shelter 2
column21:
I would really suggest that you go and play the first one before deciding whether to purchase Shelter 2.

Pros:
- The art style is absolutely gorgeous
column23:
atmospheric soundtrack.
- Controls feel very smooth.
- Much more expansive world.

Cons:
- Repetitive. Most of your time will be spent chasing rabbits.
- The tutorial tips are a bit too minimal. They lack explanation and function in favour of looking stylish.
- Too easy. Food is plentiful and I honestly didn't feel like my kits were at risk at any time.
- No replay value. You can raise more cubs
column24: but you'll still spend most of your time chasing rabbits.\n"

reviewText: I LOVE this game. To me it is an awesome game! A few glitches here and there, but that is fine with me. Hey, do you think for shelter 3 (maybe) you could do a fox? greatest game of all time\n
10/10 would feel for pixels again

I was amazingly scared when the night suddenly hit and I was caught pretty far away from my den along with my cubs. It was a worrying experience since I have no idea what dangers might lie in the night. Constantly checking where my cubs were, the entire time back. My senses being spent entirely on being able to react in case something does happen. The next day came and now my cub is sick, and it's a thunderstorm outside. There is no prey to catch, and I have to stay with my cubs through the storm. I have no idea what to do. I am absolutely freaking out and worrying to the point that I want to cry out of frustration. WHAT DO I DO ABOUT THE SICK CUB?! Highly stimulating game, definitely a must-try. The art style might be repulsive to some, but that was one of the reasons I got it, it's pretty unique. Patchwork artstyle used in a game makes the game stand out.

Do you want to be an animal out in the wilderness?! Do you love kittens?! Do you enjoy fun?! Do you enjoy a good art direction and music?! Do you like exploring at your own pace?! Of course you do... It's why you have decided to buy this game. NOW!!!!

i've played this game for 105 minutes and it made my cry like a little ♥♥♥♥♥. Sincerely recommend not to buy this game if You're very sensitive. Although, playing it will teach You life. Play at Your own risk. By far, i think this is the most beautiful game ever made. Absolutely love it

Let me just say for the record that if you cry or get attached to things easily, you probably don't want to play this game in the middle of the night. I lost one cub of the four on my first try but I cried and cried when I couldn't get it to get up. I had to keep moving and finding food for my little family, but this was an experience I was not expecting and when the credits rolled - after only 2 hours I was so attached that I didn't want it to end.

MOUNTAINS DLC + Shelter 2: This game has been quite lovely, the art-style giving a new feeling then just realistic graphics. It's a game that succsessfully pulled some of my emotions, especially stress, as it is almost always in the back of your mind. It's meant to be explored this game, all the while having something to do, although it doesn't change. I'd say once you've succsessfully raised your cubs pleanty of times, it becomes less of the game it was, HOWEVER, playing after a long break from the game is almost like getting the game the first time, just with the extra knowledge and skill.

Basically,
Pros:
- Art Style
- Animation / Models
- Music and sound effects
- Your cubs
- Return to the game as one of them, in adulthood
- Optional Collecables
- Survival Mode
- You can continue playing around after the cubs leave (Can get a little boring, but its fun to toy around with the wolves)
Cons:
- It's repeating the same Feed and Protect

... Darn, can't think of any other cons. Personally.
I would recconmend some things, but probably a bit out of reach.
- Possible animal selection. Example would be to play as a bear or wolf.
- Predators such as foxes walk around instead of spawn
- More pelts for other animals, like white foxes
- Possibly able to see other predators walk around and hunt, like a lone wolf.

All in all, I really enjoyed this game. It's honestly stunning.

i love this game its really fun but the only things i dont like is the winter is too hard and its really sad when the kittens starve and die so yea if you could just make it a little easier i would love that thank you

it's a pretty short game and there isn't much to do other than hunt for food and collect stuff ,but watching my lynx children grow up and leave me because i was old and crotchety gave me a case of the feels.

One of the first games that nearly made me cry, it is a beautifully made game, with breathtaking graphics. I lost one of my cubs and felt heartbroken, but when i saw the 3 other cubs grow up, and run off, i felt so happy. Even though i wasnt actually a mom too cubs, it surely felt like it. I surely think people should buy this game.
The game was great and relaxing but isnt worth the more than 5$

If you love collecting things, then this game is both good and bad. The good is that it's perfect for any avid treasure hunter, even having secret skins which can be unlocked by finding everything, but it falls short with the lack of steam cloud support. It was quite disappointing when I switched to a new computer and saw that my progress had been lost. The family tree disappears as well.
Kind of kills the replayability for me.

Either way, its a fun game. You play as a mother Lynx as you explore the open world terrain to find food and 'shelter' your cubs from danger. These dangers can be unexpected and unpredictable, and unless you act quickly, a life may be lost.

Some things are shrouded in mystery and gives you a feeling of errieness to the world of Shelter. Though most of which causes the creepy atmosphere is the wonderful veriety of music. The music is great and really does set the tone for the game.
its very deep and i loved it\n

A fun survival game that put you in a perspective of a mother lynx. it gives you an understanding of how hard it is being a mother and losing her kids, animal kingdom or not.  I love all of the parts of the game, I especaily love the graphics. However, if you do not like death of animals, I would not recomend this game.

Shelter 2 is by far one of my most favorite games. The atmosphere is beautiful and the artwork is magnificent. The controls are a little tricky, but you get used to it after a while.
The game itself can be heartbreaking. Since you must provide for your cubs, you become attached to them, so once one goes missing you actually start to worry. That plus the fact that the cubs cry at you when they are in the midst of dying is a great ploy to tear out tears from the players.
Hunting and exploration in the game is great. With the ability to sense/smell your prey before you even see them is nice. Plus the fact that you can kill eagles is pretty awesome.
I'd go on and on about this game but it's getting late. Basically, if you like casual games and like to feel like your heart is being pulled out, then get Shelter 2.

The gameplay the soundtrack and the visuals are so f*cking good in this game. You play as a lynx and raise 4 cubs till their adulthood, and every second is a ticking clock for one of them to expire. 200/10 would having a crying breakdown again.

This game is pretty heart touching. I was never a big fan of playing through indie-games or any game relative to this manor.

It is a short game I completed my first play through within 1-2hours.

You start as a Lynx being chased by wolves, as you run with haste to find a den to give birth to your four cubs. ( All four cubs can be named to your like.)
After birth you hunt for food to feed your cubs and your self.
In my play through all four of my cubs survived, through the end of Winter to the next I watched my four cubs grow and at the start of autumn, when the hills shimmer red you must see them off into the wilderness.
You then join your life long compainion.

Over all I give this game an 8/10
Pros -
-Heart Touching
-Cute graphical art style
-Easy to learn controls
-Multiple Play throughs
-Vast open world to roam through
-Amazing music

Cons -
-No use of shelter/den after the first night.
-Not a wide variety of animals to hunt,
-No use of real suvival elements i.e Weather change effects, a need to consume water, shelter etc.
-Limited controls, even though the game has an easy to  learn control set it is very limited in what you can do. I would suggest in the future adding in a more indepth control scheme such as buttons to allow your cubs to follow or stay, and to hunt with you as they get older.


If you enjoy indie survival games, this would be a great pick overall. Its very heart warming expierence, I even had a tear in my eye as I saw my cubs off.

This game is beautiful! No matter if you're a new player, or a returning one, this game is for you! This game features you playing as a mother lynx raising her lynx cubs. This game is a survival game. Hunt deer, rabbits, and other animals to feed your cubs. If you get the Shetler 2: Mountains DLC you will get more animals including grizzly bears, foxes, arctic foxes, rain, fires, and soo much more - A huge mountain for you to explore too! This game is absolutely breath-taking. The way the seasons change is beautiful. Watch your game go from spring to fall. Fall to winter. This game is amazing. Feed your cubs equally - or you will get an awful suprise of one of your other cubs starving. Sometimes you will be travelling and will find a suprise..Wolves, wolves will come out of nowhere when they are hungry. Watch out! In order to avoid them jump up to a high place or else you will be traumatized by what will happen to you and your cubs....Come play Shelter 2! :steamhappy:

It was a worrying experience since I have no idea what dangers might lie in the night. Constantly checking where my cubs were, the entire time back. My senses being spent entirely on being able to react in case something does happen. The next day came and now my cub is sick, and it's a thunderstorm outside. There is no prey to catch, and I have to stay with my cubs through the storm. I have no idea what to do. I am absolutely freaking out and worrying to the point that I want to cry out of frustration. WHAT DO I DO ABOUT THE SICK CUB?! Highly stimulating game, definitely a must-try. The art style might be repulsive to some, but that was one of the reasons I got it, it's pretty unique. Patchwork artstyle used in a game makes the game stand out.

I have to say, with the new updates to the game my opinion has completely been swayed.  I thought before that while adorable and somewhat suspenceful at times, that the game didn't have enough drive to get me out there exploring.  Well, with all the new content, added prey, and what not I have to say I just spent two hours exploring a LONG ways away from the den.  Loved every moment of it.

I LOVE this game. To me it is an awesome game! A few glitches here and there, but that is fine with me. Hey, do you think for shelter 3 (maybe) you could do a fox? It kinda seems to do with the game's choice of animals to me, plus the fox has been in both games. Or at least something in the dog family, but if you don't do a shelter 3, it is fine with me, I can see how hard it must be for you. But anyways, this is an awesome game, and I love it!

I've been eyeing this game for a long time here and there, and when I finally got a gaming computer and it went on sale, I had my chance to try it out. That said, I wasn't completely let down, but it didn't come close to blowing me out of the water either. I honestly can't decide whether to give it a thumbs up or not because it has good aspects, but a lot of it is very stale and lacking in potential.

The art style is great and incredibly unique, I've never seen anything quite like it before. It manages to look very hand-painted despite being 3d rendered, and isn't so bizarre that its disorienting. The main selling point for this game is probably the art style.

On to less appreciable things: gameplay, potential, and overall opinion.

I've got a beast of a computer, but I think this game is just coded in such a way that it begins to shoot itself in the foot after 15 minutes of playtime. Framerate goes right in the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ regardless of graphics settings, and I had to close and reopen the game every so often just to be able to even play it. (Maybe something to do with the data endlessley compiling and not wiping itself when you leave an area and it becomes no longer relevant? Who knows.)

In between dealing with the game running like molasses for no discernible reason, I found myself struggling to rationalize a reason to play it beyond getting a few easy achievements. The point is simple: sniff, find a rabbit or whatever, run at it and hope the game doesn't lag so badly you can't catch it before your kittens starve. There's no direction- you just wander around and kill stuff over and over until your kittens grow up and start killing their own stuff, by which point you are mostly superfluous- and then they leave, and you go home. That's it.

A few freak events make it kind of interesting, but its mostly just annoying because the fires and lightning strikes and floods are almost guaranteed to kill at least one kitten if you don't run like hell, and they look choppy as if they were thrown in last minute. I spent a good two minutes in a flood" before I realized what it was supposed to be
date: I just thought the game was glitching at first.\n\nBasically
recommended: get this game only if it goes on a reeealllyy good sale and you don't have high expectations."

Once you get to playing it's hard not to believe these lynx cubs aren't your biological children

Shelter 2 is far greater than the original in so many ways. The art style, the development, and the storyline all feel like it's been improved immensely. The world is vast and open, making you feel like you really have the map to breath in around you. Even the cubs are downright adorable, making you feel attached as soon as you begin to care for them. You can even name them.

However this game could use a tiny bit more explanation of how to play in the beginning. It comes off as a little confusing, and hunting techniques take a really long time to understand and develop. To be honest though, this makes it feel more realistic in the facts that real life doesn't come with a manual on how to play.

The first time I actually lost a cub was very heart wrenching for me, and each time I lost another, I lost more motivation to keep playing. The attachment you grow with them (if you're not completely heartless, or if you're just a big softy like me) is huge and you'll probably  get annoyed every time you get close to loosing one in a storm, to a predator, or even starvation.

Fun, espiecally for kids. I love how you can trancend into the world of the lynx. It really makes you feel attached to the cubs. I get sad every time I fail to provide for them, I feel like it's my fault, like I always could have done better.

Shelter 2, despite me only playing it for a few hours, was one of the best games I've played. It shows both the hardship of motherhood, and the sacrifices made to it when trying to survive. It really made me feel for mothers and I think I can take this game's message with me for my life, unlike almost any other game i've played. The gameplay is wonderful, the world is beautiful, and the story, despite being short and simple, was moving. I love this game, and I think I'm going to replay it a few more times through the years, before I force myself to move on, and I will never forget this. When a bad thing happened to my cub, i got confused, and started to be worried and I wandered for about 10 minutes before coming to terms with what happened. In addition, there were many times where i became worried for my cubs and myself, and I really felt it. Shelter 2 is absolutely unforgetable, and i think enyone with a heart should play it. invaluable experience

One of the most beautiful games I think I have ever played. So far, it's not the most exciting, but the sheer beauty makes up for that, and I'm sure the game will pick up as I progress further. Definitelly recommended.

Other reviews put a bit too much emotion into what this game really is.

No doubt, it's different and relaxing. And in the end it is really sad
However it's short and figuring out the mechanics is frustrating. When a cub was starting to die I felt less sadness and more frustration because if you don't play it correctly the cubs most certainly will be pining for your attention often.

If you can help it you should opt to play this game in a focused environment where you can 100% immerse and devote yourself to creating the world to suite you. If the game was longer, with more content, and better controls the replay value would up tremendously.

All in all, it's a roleplay game. If you can get it discount you should grab it. The art style is lovely.

One of my cubs starved to death because it wouldn't eat the frog I caught for it.

...

10/10 would agonize over picky lynx kittens again.

This game is so adorable yet so sad at the same time, and the animation, style, and music is beautiful. I felt terrible when my first kit died, i didn't know what was happening or what to do, but i think this is how the game is trying to show it's lesson.  It lets you experience loss yourself so you can understand the fact that life is hard, no matter how hard you try.  The small amount of  instruction i thought was really nice; you get a chance to figure things out and explore yourself, which I haven't seen in many games, and it isn't too compilcated that you don't know what to. Even if you aren't into the exploration and finding all the collectibles, I still think it's worth at least one play through. It gave be a new understanding of life and nature, and a greater appreciation of mothers.

A lovely short(ish) game.

You play a lynx mum, defending your lynx babies from nature, and taking care of them until they're grown, while around you the landscape changes with the seasons.

The art style is lovely, and the music is very relaxing. Controls are only for moving, jumping, and scenting (seeing/smelling things, highlighting prey and enemies), with little explanation, but it's all pretty intuitive.

This is one of those games that didnt seem like it was gonna be somethin you would remember forever, but after playing it through just once i know ill never be able to forget it. It was something that you can play for a good while to pass the time, or sit down and just immerse yourself in this unique world wroght with peril for you and your cubs, or rolling hills. This game, for all intents and purposes, made me cry like a ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥ at the end.\n\nNow, im going to call my mom and tell her how much she means to me.
