reviewText: The game was great and relaxing but isnt worth the more than 5$

MOUNTAINS DLC + Shelter 2: This game has been quite lovely, the art-style giving a new feeling then just realistic graphics. It's a game that succsessfully pulled some of my emotions, especially stress, as it is almost always in the back of your mind. It's meant to be explored this game, all the while having something to do, although it doesn't change. I'd say once you've succsessfully raised your cubs pleanty of times, it becomes less of the game it was, HOWEVER, playing after a long break from the game is almost like getting the game the first time, just with the extra knowledge and skill.

Basically,
Pros:
- Art Style
- Animation / Models
- Music and sound effects
- Your cubs
- Return to the game as one of them, in adulthood
- Optional Collecables
- Survival Mode
- You can continue playing around after the cubs leave (Can get a little boring, but its fun to toy around with the wolves)
Cons:
- It's repeating the same Feed and Protect

... Darn, can't think of any other cons. Personally.
I would recconmend some things, but probably a bit out of reach.
- Possible animal selection. Example would be to play as a bear or wolf.
- Predators such as foxes walk around instead of spawn
- More pelts for other animals, like white foxes
- Possibly able to see other predators walk around and hunt, like a lone wolf.

All in all, I really enjoyed this game. It's honestly stunning.
Hands down, one off the best games ive ever played. Can be stresfull, but you will fall inlove with it. I hope they make a shelter 3 with deer or somthing.
There are a lot of games that are 20 to 60 hours in lengh that cannot create nearly as strong of an emotional response that this game makes in less than 2.

Oh, this game...
What to say about this game...

Shelter 2 is an interesting game.
You get to be a Lynx momma, who's got four cute little Lynx cubs that need to be taken care of.
You gotta go hunting, make sure they stay fed, and safe.
It's a short game, but don't let that fool you, it's still good in my own opinion. The story is minimalist, but still managed to touch lil' ol' me, and tug on my heartstrings, and give me goosebumps AND give me a sense of discovery and satisfaction.
I truly did enjoy this game, for what it was worth.
though i do think $15 is kinda steep

Also, I highly recommend a controller. It makes the game much easier to play when you have all the needed commands LITERALLY at your fingertips.
(and you can remap them, too!)

So I'd give this a solid 93/100

This game isn't exactly 'action-packed', but more of a sentimental rollercoaster of emotions.

Pride seeing my kits born and leaving the den.
Grief when I lost my oldest kit, Kiva, to wolves in the night.
Weariness of constant hunting to keep the other three kits from collapsing in the cold winter storm.
Pride again when they caught their first rabbit.
Loss when they grew up and left my side.

But the game hit me really hard in the feels when it was time to leave Earth and walk among the stars, where I met Kiva, who I lost so long ago.

Though a little short, Shelter 2 is overall an amazing game with great ambience, graphics and music. I give this 8.5/10

If you played the original Shelter game and loved it, but wanted more freedom, this game is perfect. As a mother lynx with four cubs (which become playable characters if they survive - you can also name them!) you explore a large map just as beautiful if not more so than the first Shelter game. Avoid wolves and catch rabbits, lemmings, frogs, pheasants and deer to keep your family alive as the seasons change. Overall the game is pretty easy-going. There's not as much of a story like there was in Shelter 1.\nThe SETTING is particularly interesting. The deer in Shelter 2 have long fangs, and I'm told fanged deer have long since been extinct. There is also a dead wooly mammoth in the glacier area of the map as well, which leads me to think Shelter 2 takes place in some sort of late ice age. VERY COOL!!! My compliments to the game developers on that one!
Rating: 5/10

Amazing game!
Just finished my first playthrough, and I'm so excited to continue my Lynx family's Legacy!

TL:DR - Lost 2 cubs, found lots of stuff, enjoyed the music and the wonderful artstyle of this game. :D

So, from what I picked up on my first playthrough was:

PROs:
- Fun/Sad survival, open world game.
- Adorable Lynx sprites.   :3
- TONS of collectables (For all us completionists.)
- Plenty of challenging Achievements to earn.
- Trial and Error learning curve.   **
- Great soundtrack! <3
- Unique artstyle that makes a baron tundra and sky seem alive.
- Time Passing and Seasons Changing!       ~ Emmersiveness
- Lots of variety in prey/predator incounters.
- Promising DLC with extra areas, prey, predators, music, and Achievements!


** Some might consider this a CON, but the challenge is rather welcome in my opinion.

CONS:
- Restrictive boundaries.
- Lack of explaination, direction, information.
- Awkward jump physics.
- No indicators of cub fatigue.
- Cubs sometimes go missing without any explaination. T_T

This game is just amazing, I got it on sale but I'm most definitely willing to support this company by buying the DLC they currently have and any more they may release for this great game. I hope everyone is willing to give this game a shot, it has something that most survival games are missing, some sort of fear or worry for the defenseless and the struggle to keep a family alive from the harsh environment.
I love the beautiful graphics

I love this game. I wont play anything without a good art style, and if your like me, you will love this game. Super simplistic and nice. All around just a very relaxing game that really shows the importance of mothers, feline or not.

If you've never played a game by Might and Delight before- play it.\nIt's a delightful survival game, where you hunt, feed and protect four lynx cubs.\nThe art style and amazing soundtrack combine to create a wonderful experience - 5/5 would recommend.

I love this game in so many ways. I loved the first one, and I love this one too. The art, soundtrack\music, and story of both games if astounding on so many levels. I do have a couple of questions though; (I have not bought the Mountains add-on yet, all though I plan too)
-In one of the videos it shows Mother Lynx, or Inna, hunting deer like creatures. I did not incounter these, although I did look the second play through, and was not succesful. Do these show up on the Mountain add-on only? Or was i just looking in the wrong places?
-Just a heads up for new player, if you care at all, you might not see those deer in the regular Shelter 2 game without the add-on, Mountains.
-I also recommend you get the Mountains add-on, I haven't yet (but I plan too), I think it will improve the gameplay tremendously.
-Also note that if you can't get the Mountains add-on, there is a setting to make gameplay harder without the add-on. Also not that it still doesn't add mountains, dont want any confusion here.
-If you read this far, then you are a very determined person with a good sense of mind, and I admire your curiosity that keeps you going. Have a wnderful day!

Why I don't reccomend this game:

What I wanted:

A lot of us really want an immersive animal simulation game including me, and this one seems to be disapointing.
What I wanted was a game where you start out as a single lynx, and you must find a mate, get pregnant and then find a den. From then you raise cubs, with different growth stages, and you must kill a wide variety of prey to feed yourself and your offspring. I also wanted  realistic weather systems and the need to keep cubs warm in the winter. I wanted a day/night cycle with different prey and predators that come out during certain time periods. And to complete the game I wanted lasting injuries, a hunger, thirst, temperature, and maybe even a sleep bar, and when you die you continue as one of your surviving cubs.

What I got:

Very pretty graphics, repetitive cut scenes, and reletively boring and repititive gameplay. I would say that the most immersive part of the game is the prey/predator system. The prey options are bunnies, deer, voles, pheasants, owl eggs, and frogs, also if you have the mountains DLC then it adds foxes and I think thats it. The predators are wolves, this extremely creepy black blob thing, and  starvation if you call that one. The mountains DLC adds eagles, foxes, bears, and forest fires.
The tutorials are very vague and confusing, and its impossible to really tell when your cubs are  hungry so you just have to feed them constantly.

Over all this is the perfect game for you if you really enjoy looking at the beautiful graphics, and like running around as a cute four-legged animal with a bunch of mini cute four-legged animals following you, catching bunnies and occasionally running away from wolves and stuff. But for the peeps who want a realistic animal life sim, this isn't the game for you.
